pomegranate_details.description: Pomegranate is a fruit-bearing deciduous shrub or small tree known for its distinctive ruby-red arils encased in a tough, leathery skin. It belongs to the family Lythraceae and is native to the Middle East.
pomegranate_details.nutritional value: Pomegranate arils are rich in antioxidants, vitamins (especially vitamin C and vitamin K), dietary fiber, and minerals (such as potassium). They support heart health, boost immunity, and may have anti-inflammatory effects.
pomegranate_details.uses: Fresh consumption, Juicing, Salads, Sauces, Desserts
pomegranate_details.varieties: Wonderful, Haku Botan, Ambrosia, Eversweet, Red Silk
pomegranate_details.ripening: Pomegranates do not ripen further after being harvested, so they are typically harvested when fully ripe.
pomegranate_details.ripeness indicator: A ripe pomegranate will have a firm, rounded shape, vibrant color, and heavy weight for its size.
pomegranate_details.harvest season: Pomegranates are typically harvested in the fall, but the exact timing varies depending on the variety and growing conditions.

prerequisites.soil: Pomegranates prefer well-drained, sandy or loamy soil with good fertility and a slightly acidic to neutral pH (around 5.5 to 7.0).
prerequisites.climate: Pomegranates thrive in Mediterranean climates with hot, dry summers and cool, wet winters. They can tolerate drought but require some chilling hours in winter for flower bud development.
prerequisites.sunlight: Pomegranates require full sunlight for optimal growth and fruit production.
prerequisites.water: Pomegranates are drought-tolerant once established but require regular watering, especially during the flowering and fruiting stages.
prerequisites.space: Plant pomegranate trees at least 10 to 12 feet apart to allow for proper air circulation and sunlight penetration.
